caption: | The uniform evolved.The commitment remained.Police officers carry up to 5kg of essential equipment including firearms, a Taser, a straight extendable baton, communications devices and handcuffs on their utility belts to support their duties.The currently on trial new Load Bearing Vest (LBV) is designed to improve officers operational efficiency and endurance, equipment capacity, and overall efficiency.It redistributes the equipment weight from the utility belt to the upper body, with handcuffs and communication devices attached directly to the vest. This reduces lower back strain and enhances officers comfort during their extended shift duties.Read more about it in our Police Life article. caption: It was 11pm on 5 September 2025 when the call came in a fire had broken out at a block of flats at Chai Chee Avenue.SI Indrawira Bin Zainal and SC/Cpl Dway Min Hlaing were nearby and raced to the scene.What they found was a block experiencing a blackout; thick, black smoke pouring from the burning unit; and confused residents in the smoke-filled corridors.When backup arrived SSSgt Wendy Sui and SSSgt Ahmad Bin Hashim the team began to evacuate residents.The real challenge awaited them on the ninth floor: an elderly, wheelchair-bound man, unable to navigate the pitch-dark corridors and unable to access the lift due to the blackout.In that critical moment, SI Indrawira said, Don't worry, I'll help you, before hoisting the elderly man onto his back.Down nine floors they went through the darkness and over wet debris with SSSgt Sui holding the elderly man's oxygen cylinder, SSSgt Ahmad carrying the wheelchair and SC/Cpl Dway lighting their path.Every step mattered. Any slip would have been dangerous.By 11.59pm, officers from Bedok and Geylang NPCs had safely evacuated every resident.Asked about his life-saving actions, SI Indrawira said, I was just doing my part as a Police officer to protect and save lives. Written by: Domnic DassPhotos by: Naveen Raj
cleaned_caption: It was 11pm on 5 September 2025 when the call came in a fire had broken out at a block of flats at Chai Chee Avenue. SI Indrawira and SC/Cpl were nearby and raced to the scene. What they found was a block experiencing a blackout; thick, black smoke pouring from the burning unit; and confused residents in the smoke-filled corridors. When backup arrived, SSSgt and SSSgt the team began to evacuate residents. The real challenge awaited them on the ninth floor: an elderly, wheelchair-bound man, unable to navigate the pitch-dark corridors and unable to access the lift due to the blackout. In that critical moment, SI Indrawira said, "Don't worry, I'll help you," before hoisting the elderly man onto his back. Down nine floors they went through the darkness and over wet debris with SSSgt holding the elderly man's oxygen cylinder, SSSgt carrying the wheelchair and SC/Cpl lighting their path. Every step mattered. Any slip would have been dangerous. By 11.59pm, officers from Bedok and Geylang NPCs had safely evacuated every resident. Asked about his life-saving actions, SI Indrawira said, "I was just doing my part as a Police officer to protect and save lives."

caption: It was 11pm on 5 September 2025 when the call came in a fire had broken out at a block of flats at Chai Chee Avenue.SI Indrawira Bin Zainal and SC/Cpl Dway Min Hlaing were nearby and raced to the scene.What they found was a block experiencing a blackout; thick, black smoke pouring from the burning unit; and confused residents in the smoke-filled corridors.When backup arrived SSSgt Wendy Sui and SSSgt Ahmad Bin Hashim the team began to evacuate residents.The real challenge awaited them on the ninth floor: an elderly, wheelchair-bound man, unable to navigate the pitch-dark corridors and unable to access the lift due to the blackout.In that critical moment, SI Indrawira said, Don't worry, I'll help you, before hoisting the elderly man onto his back.Down nine floors they went through the darkness and over wet debris with SSSgt Sui holding the elderly man's oxygen cylinder, SSSgt Ahmad carrying the wheelchair and SC/Cpl Dway lighting their path.Every step mattered. Any slip would have been dangerous.By 11.59pm, officers from Bedok and Geylang NPCs had safely evacuated every resident.Asked about his life-saving actions, SI Indrawira said, I was just doing my part as a Police officer to protect and save lives. Written by: Domnic DassPhotos by: Naveen Raj
cleaned_caption: It was 11pm on 5 September 2025 when the call came in a fire had broken out at a block of flats at Chai Chee Avenue. SI Indrawira and SC/Cpl were nearby and raced to the scene. What they found was a block experiencing a blackout; thick, black smoke pouring from the burning unit; and confused residents in the smoke-filled corridors. When backup arrived SSSgt and SSSgt the team began to evacuate residents. The real challenge awaited them on the ninth floor: an elderly, wheelchair-bound man, unable to navigate the pitch-dark corridors and unable to access the lift due to the blackout. In that critical moment, SI Indrawira said, Don't worry, I'll help you, before hoisting the elderly man onto his back. Down nine floors they went through the darkness and over wet debris with SSSgt holding the elderly man's oxygen cylinder, SSSgt carrying the wheelchair and SC/Cpl lighting their path. Every step mattered. Any slip would have been dangerous. By 11.59pm, officers from Bedok and Geylang NPCs had safely evacuated every resident. Asked about his life-saving actions, SI Indrawira said, I was just doing my part as a Police officer to protect and save lives.

caption: The Singapore Police Force (SPF) held a Change of Command Ceremony on 5 January 2026 at the Home Team Academy, where Mr How Kwang Hwee formally assumed office as Commissioner of Police, succeeding Mr Hoong Wee Teck.Mr Hoong Wee Teck led the SPF for 11 years and served the Force for 38 years. Under his leadership, the SPF strengthened its capabilities through technology-driven policing, including the use of unmanned aerial vehicles, a nationwide police camera network with video analytics, and the establishment of the Anti-Scam Command and Emergency Response Teams. Singapore has remained one of the safest cities in the world, with consistently low crime rates and high public trust in the SPF.With 27 years of service, Mr How has held key leadership appointments across policy, operations, investigations, and intelligence. He brings deep operational experience and a strong commitment to public safety.We thank Mr Hoong Wee Teck for his years of dedicated service and leadership.The Singapore Police Force remains steadfast in its mission to keep Singapore safe and secure.

He brings deep operational experience and a strong commitment to public safety. The Singapore Police Force remains steadfast in its mission to keep Singapore safe and secure.

answer_0: The presence of police dogs in MRT stations, such as the City Hall MRT depicted in the image, significantly enhances community safety and crime prevention in several ways. Firstly, the visible deployment of a police dog, as seen with the officer holding its leash, serves as a deterrent to potential criminal activity. The strong presence of canine units can instill a sense of security among commuters, reassuring them that public safety measures are actively in place.

Additionally, police dogs are trained for specific purposes, such as detecting narcotics or explosives, which enhances the effectiveness of security measures in busy transport environments. With the station bustling with commuters, the dog’s presence allows for increased surveillance without overwhelming human resources, enabling officers to maintain a proactive approach to safety as observed in the image where officers are vigilant while patrolling.

Furthermore, having well-trained police dogs on patrol encourages community engagement, fostering a positive relationship between law enforcement and the public. Commuters may be more inclined to approach and report suspicious activities to an officer with a police dog, contributing to a collaborative atmosphere in safety efforts. Overall, the integration of police dogs in MRT stations is a vital component of Singapore's comprehensive crime prevention strategy, enhancing both security and community trust.

caption: The Singapore Police Force (SPF) Band commemorated its 100th anniversary with a gala concert on 30 December 2025 at the Esplanade Concert Hall with Ms Sim Ann, Senior Minister of State for Ministry of Foreign Affairs & Ministry of Home Affairs, as the Guest-of-Honour.More than 1,000 guests attended the gala concert which marked the culmination of a year of celebration of the SPF Bands journey from its beginnings as the Second Straits Settlement Police Band in 1925, to Singapores oldest uniformed band in 2025. Themed "Bringing the Beat to You Since 1925, the concert featured the SPF Bands iconic pieces from across the decades, including renditions of various classic music pieces, as well as original compositions and arrangements by current and past SPF Band officers. A special composition titled "Bringing the Beat to You" written by Director of Music SUPT Sulaiman Abdul Wahab was also premiered at the concert. The concert also showcased ethnic dancers from various SPF units as well as seven members of the public from the Episodic Volunteering Programme performing alongside the Band, demonstrating community collaboration and the Bands unifying role within the SPF. Ex-PNSF Taufik Batisah who did his national service with the SPF Band was also among the performers. The SPF Band has inspired through music, united communities, and represented the SPF with distinction on countless stages locally and around the world over a century. The concert celebrates not only history and growth, but also the passion, artistry, and devotion of every officerpast and presentwhose contributions have woven the rich tapestry of our enduring legacy.spfpolicelife safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce spfband

caption: : After joining SPF as an NSF in 1984 and returning as an Inspector in 1992, SAC Puvenesveran has dedicated over 36 years of service to the Force, including more than 2 decades with the Gurkha Contingent, before taking on his current role as Director of the Police National Service Department (PNSD) in 2020.When asked about a defining moment in his career, SAC Puvenesveran candidly shared that it was when he met a former offender on the street who thanked him for investigating a case that changed his life and made him a better father. "These are the unrecognised but big positive changes that every SPF officer does every day," he reflects.As a leader, he believes that "Great Leaders are not born. They are MADE by Greater Followers." SAC Puvenesveran values investing in officers by forming the team, training the team, and trusting the team. To all officers, he shares five key principles: what we do has value, challenges are opportunities to improve ourselves, we all have choices so make the right ones, when we don the blue, we must hold ourselves to higher standards and remember that bad days don't equal a bad life.What SAC Puvenesveran finds most impactful about the work that PNSD does is knowing that the staff at PNSD has made a positive difference to thousands of NSFs and NSmen, making each PNS officer's National Service journey a meaningful one. Beyond his role as Director PNSD, he serves as General Secretary of HomeTeamNS, working to balance the call for officers to serve, with opportunities for them and their families to connect and play.Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim.Photos by Ong Lin Hui.spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday pns50

caption: : After joining SPF as an NSF in 1984 and returning as an Inspector in 1992, SAC Puvenesveran has dedicated over 36 years of service to the Force, including more than 2 decades with the Gurkha Contingent, before taking on his current role as Director of the Police National Service Department (PNSD) in 2020.When asked about a defining moment in his career, SAC Puvenesveran candidly shared that it was when he met a former offender on the street who thanked him for investigating a case that changed his life and made him a better father. "These are the unrecognised but big positive changes that every SPF officer does every day," he reflects.As a leader, he believes that "Great Leaders are not born. They are MADE by Greater Followers." SAC Puvenesveran values investing in officers by forming the team, training the team, and trusting the team. To all officers, he shares five key principles: what we do has value, challenges are opportunities to improve ourselves, we all have choices so make the right ones, when we don the blue, we must hold ourselves to higher standards and remember that bad days don't equal a bad life.What SAC Puvenesveran finds most impactful about the work that PNSD does is knowing that the staff at PNSD has made a positive difference to thousands of NSFs and NSmen, making each PNS officer's National Service journey a meaningful one. Beyond his role as Director PNSD, he serves as General Secretary of HomeTeamNS, working to balance the call for officers to serve, with opportunities for them and their families to connect and play.Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim.Photos by Ong Lin Hui.spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday pns50
cleaned_caption: After joining the Singapore Police Force (SPF) as an NSF in 1984 and returning as an Inspector in 1992, SAC has dedicated over 36 years of service to the Force, including more than two decades with the Gurkha Contingent, before taking on his current role as Director of the Police National Service Department (PNSD) in 2020. When asked about a defining moment in his career, SAC candidly shared that it was when he met a former offender on the street who thanked him for investigating a case that changed his life and made him a better father. "These are the unrecognised but big positive changes that every SPF officer does every day," he reflects. As a leader, he believes that "Great Leaders are not born. They are MADE by Greater Followers." SAC values investing in officers by forming the team, training the team, and trusting the team. To all officers, he shares five key principles: what we do has value, challenges are opportunities to improve ourselves, we all have choices so make the right ones, when we don the blue, we must hold ourselves to higher standards, and remember that bad days don't equal a bad life. What he finds most impactful about the work that PNSD does is knowing that the staff at PNSD has made a positive difference to thousands of NSFs and NSmen, making each PNS officer's National Service journey a meaningful one. Beyond his role as Director PNSD, he serves as General Secretary of HomeTeamNS, working to balance the call for officers to serve, with opportunities for them and their families to connect and play. Produced by. Photos by. spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday pns50

caption: ! SSS Ithnin Bin Md Salleh, SGT Sia Wan Xin, SGT Cheung Kiau Shuen, SGT Melrize Ng Sumei, SGT Muhammad Raihan Bin Roslan, SGT (V) Neo Yi Wen and their fellow teammates Muhammad Taufiq bin Mahmud and Yap E-Rong Andre delivered their finest performance, securing Singapore a bronze medal at the recently concluded SEA Games 2025 in Mixed 560KG Tug of War.Bringing home the bronze medal was no easy feat for our SPF officers and their teammates, requiring months of gruelling training, unwavering determination, and the strength to pull together as one united force. From balancing police duties to intensive training sessions, our six officers exemplified what it means to serve Singapore both on duty and on the sporting stage."Representing Singapore is a tremendous honour for us," SSS Ithnin shared on behalf of the team. "We are proud to wear our country's colours, showcasing our strength and teamwork to other nations."The journey was not without its challenges. Facing experienced opponents and pushing through injuries tested their resolve, but for our SPF officers, their police training proved invaluable. The discipline, teamwork, and ability to remain calm under pressure that defines their police work became their secret weapons in the competition arena.Together with the strong support from their teammates Taufiq and Andre, who understood the challenges of balancing shift work and training sessions, they were united and unstoppable."During the match, we focused on our strategy and on supporting each other. We kept reminding ourselves to stay strong and pull together as a team," they reflected. "Winning bronze at the SEA Games' Mixed 560KG Tug of War is an amazing feeling for us! We are thrilled to be bringing home a medal for Singapore. It is a dream come true."This is what it means to serve Singapore whether keeping our communities safe or representing our nation with pride. singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday pns50 TeamSingapore SEAGames2025

caption: : - In 2001, 19-year-old Police full-time National Serviceman (PNSF) Shaikh Abdullah was in the Criminal Investigation Departments (CID) operations room during a kidnap-for-ransom case. As he made calls to support the investigation, he watched officers from different units work seamlessly together. When the case was successfully resolved, the collective sense of relief and accomplishment was unmistakable. It was an all-hands-on-deck moment that would spark a lifelong commitment to serviceToday, as the NS Commander of the Airport Police Division (APD), Supt (NS) Shaikh Abdullah leads 1,300 Police National Service (PNS) officers. Looking back on his time with the Singapore Police Force, he reflects on a journey that has taken him from the gritty undercover operations of the now-defunct Charlie Division, through critical roles in CID, to his current command at APD a path that has continued to shape his approach to leadership and service.I believe that as a responsible member of a community, one should contribute beyond taking care of oneself and ones family. Being an active PNSman is one small way I contribute.His service forged more than skills it shaped a career spanning nearly two decades in aviation security and instilled values that now guide him as Deputy Director of Airport Operations and Aviation Security at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) The professionalism and skill of CID officers set a high standard for what excellence means, he reflects. It showed a 19-year-old PNSF how dedication and expertise drive an organisation forward.Beyond his career, those formative years transformed his lifestyle. The long Sunday morning runs that began with the late Mr Sri Kanthan and Field Instructor Yusman? Still his weekly routine, 25 years on.As we mark PNS50, we celebrate officers like Supt (NS) Shaikh Abdullah whose dedication reminds us that service isnt just a duty; its a calling that shapes lives, careers and communitiespns50 safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce
cleaned_caption: In 2001, a 19-year-old Police full-time National Serviceman (PNSF) was in the Criminal Investigation Departments (CID) operations room during a kidnap-for-ransom case. As he made calls to support the investigation, he watched officers from different units work seamlessly together. When the case was successfully resolved, the collective sense of relief and accomplishment was unmistakable. It was an all-hands-on-deck moment that would spark a lifelong commitment to service. Today, as the NS Commander of the Airport Police Division (APD), he leads 1,300 Police National Service (PNS) officers. Looking back on his time with the Singapore Police Force, he reflects on a journey that has taken him from the gritty undercover operations of the now-defunct Charlie Division, through critical roles in CID, to his current command at APD, a path that has continued to shape his approach to leadership and service. He believes that as a responsible member of a community, one should contribute beyond taking care of oneself and one's family. Being an active PNSman is one small way to contribute. His service forged more than skills; it shaped a career spanning nearly two decades in aviation security and instilled values that now guide him as Deputy Director of Airport Operations and Aviation Security at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS). The professionalism and skill of CID officers set a high standard for what excellence means, he reflects. It showed a 19-year-old PNSF how dedication and expertise drive an organisation forward. Beyond his career, those formative years transformed his lifestyle. The long Sunday morning runs that began with a late individual and Field Instructor? Still his weekly routine, 25 years on. As we mark PNS50, we celebrate officers like him whose dedication reminds us that service isn't just a duty; it's a calling that shapes lives, careers, and communities.

caption: : - In 2001, 19-year-old Police full-time National Serviceman (PNSF) Shaikh Abdullah was in the Criminal Investigation Departments (CID) operations room during a kidnap-for-ransom case. As he made calls to support the investigation, he watched officers from different units work seamlessly together. When the case was successfully resolved, the collective sense of relief and accomplishment was unmistakable. It was an all-hands-on-deck moment that would spark a lifelong commitment to serviceToday, as the NS Commander of the Airport Police Division (APD), Supt (NS) Shaikh Abdullah leads 1,300 Police National Service (PNS) officers. Looking back on his time with the Singapore Police Force, he reflects on a journey that has taken him from the gritty undercover operations of the now-defunct Charlie Division, through critical roles in CID, to his current command at APD a path that has continued to shape his approach to leadership and service.I believe that as a responsible member of a community, one should contribute beyond taking care of oneself and ones family. Being an active PNSman is one small way I contribute.His service forged more than skills it shaped a career spanning nearly two decades in aviation security and instilled values that now guide him as Deputy Director of Airport Operations and Aviation Security at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) The professionalism and skill of CID officers set a high standard for what excellence means, he reflects. It showed a 19-year-old PNSF how dedication and expertise drive an organisation forward.Beyond his career, those formative years transformed his lifestyle. The long Sunday morning runs that began with the late Mr Sri Kanthan and Field Instructor Yusman? Still his weekly routine, 25 years on.As we mark PNS50, we celebrate officers like Supt (NS) Shaikh Abdullah whose dedication reminds us that service isnt just a duty; its a calling that shapes lives, careers and communitiespns50 safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce

When the case was successfully resolved, the collective sense of relief and accomplishment was unmistakable. It was an all-hands-on-deck moment that would spark a lifelong commitment to service. Today, as the NS Commander of the Airport Police Division (APD), he leads 1,300 Police National Service (PNS) officers. Looking back on his time with the Singapore Police Force, he reflects on a journey that has taken him from the gritty undercover operations of the now-defunct Charlie Division, through critical roles in CID, to his current command at APD – a path that has continued to shape his approach to leadership and service. He believes that as a responsible member of a community, one should contribute beyond taking care of oneself and one's family. Being an active PNSman is one small way he contributes. His service forged more than skills; it shaped a career spanning nearly two decades in aviation security and instilled values that now guide him as Deputy Director of Airport Operations and Aviation Security at the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS). The professionalism and skill of CID officers set a high standard for what excellence means, he reflects. It showed a 19-year-old PNSF how dedication and expertise drive an organization forward. Beyond his career, those formative years transformed his lifestyle. The long Sunday morning runs that began with others remain his weekly routine, 25 years on. As we mark PNS50, we celebrate officers like him whose dedication reminds us that service isn't just a duty; it's a calling that shapes lives, careers and communities.

caption: ! From the police uniform to the dobok this is a story of a champion who serves Singapore in more ways than one.SC/SGT Nicholas Khaw and his partner Diyanah Aqidah have etched their names in history, clinching Singapores first gold at the 2025 Bangkok SEA Games in mixed poomsae pair taekwondo.Behind this golden moment lies a story of extraordinary dedication, duty and discipline. On weekdays, Nicholas reports for duty at the Police Logistics Department (PLD), assisting with the logistical requirements for police operations, before heading for training after work hours. Weekends? More training. The body exhausted, the mind tested, but the spirit unbreakable. Because when you represent Singapore, you give everything.After making mistakes in the first two rounds, I lost confidence, Nicholas shares with raw honesty.But with my coaches help, I calmed down and focused. I wasnt thinking about winning I just wanted to do my best for my teammate, our coaches, our sport, and our country.That mindset delivered gold. This is what it means to serve Singapore whether protecting our streets or representing our nation on the world stage. This is what it means to push through doubt, fatigue, and pressure. This is what it means to inspire the next generation of athletes who dare to dream.Nicholas credits his family and his team at PLD for their unwavering support, reminding us that behind every champion stands a community that believes.To Nicholas and Diyanah: Congratulations! Your sacrifice, grit, and heart have come to fruition. Youve made us incredibly proud!To all our Team Singapore athletes competing at SEA Games 2025: Were behind you all the way! [Photos: fashionisland]singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday pns50 TeamSingapore SEAGames2025

caption: : & The trust that citizens place in us to safeguard their wellbeing is both humbling and energising. DSP Stanley shared, as he looks back at his 33-year career with the SPF. Growing up, DSP Stanley witnessed firsthand how the presence of dedicated police officers could make a genuine difference in people's lives during their most vulnerable moments. DSP Stanley started as Police National Serviceman (PNSF) in 1992 and became regular in 1994 with the 'Best Trainee' award. DSP Stanley Tan is currently Officer-In-Charge (OC) Public Entertainment & Liquor Licensing Division at the Police Regulatory Department (PRD). Officers like DSP Stanley are gazetted with powers under the law to ensure that only persons who meet the fit and proper criteria may be granted approvals and licences and conversely, revoke or suspend the approvals and licences if these persons no longer meet the fit and proper criteria. DSP Stanley shares that PRD work is especially impactful as it serves as a bridge between demands we must protect the public interest whilst enabling legitimate business activities to flourish. When asked about the most memorable moment from his 33-years in service, he fondly shared that his experiences within each posting taught him something valuable. However, a juncture in his career that greatly impacted him was when he had to deal with a public order case. After the case had concluded, the young offenders returned with their parents - not in trouble, but to thank him. They said being treated fairly during the investigation helped them turn their lives around. That's when he truly understood the impact of police work goes beyond just solving cases.To young officers, DSP Stanleys advice is that everything happens for a reason! What might initially seem like setbacks or diversions often become the experiences that shape you into a more well-rounded officer and leader. Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim. Photos by Ong Lin Hui.spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: " ": On 15 November 2025, Station Inspector (SI) Ramdzan and his teammates, Sgt Yi Xiang and Sgt Sherwin from the Police Coast Guard spotted a small fishing boat in Singapore waters. What happened next would touch thousands of hearts online.Seeing two nervous Malaysian fishermen, SI Ramdzan adopted a friendly approach when engaging them. "I told them I understood they might have accidentally entered Singapore waters and they would need to return to Malaysian waters." The fishermen complied immediately.Unknown to him, someone filmed the interaction. The video went viral, with netizens affectionately calling him "Abang Police." His wife's reaction touched him most: "She actually laughed and said she was proud of me."The term "Abang Police" particularly moved him. "When people use that term, there's something much more meaningful behind it. 'Abang' is like calling someone a protective older brother, someone you can trust."SI Ramdzan shared, "Being professional and firm doesn't mean we have to be cold or aggressive. We're dealing with people who deserve to be treated with dignity and respect."His approach wasn't just about enforcement it was about building trust, one interaction at a time. Sometimes the most powerful moments happen when duty meets humanity. Kudos to SI Ramdzan and his team!singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: On 15 November 2025, Station Inspector (SI) and his teammates, Sgt and Sgt from the Police Coast Guard spotted a small fishing boat in Singapore waters. What happened next would touch thousands of hearts online. Seeing two nervous Malaysian fishermen, SI adopted a friendly approach when engaging them. "I told them I understood they might have accidentally entered Singapore waters and they would need to return to Malaysian waters." The fishermen complied immediately. Unknown to him, someone filmed the interaction. The video went viral, with netizens affectionately calling him "Abang Police." His wife's reaction touched him most: "She actually laughed and said she was proud of me." The term "Abang Police" particularly moved him. "When people use that term, there's something much more meaningful behind it. 'Abang' is like calling someone a protective older brother, someone you can trust." SI shared, "Being professional and firm doesn't mean we have to be cold or aggressive. We're dealing with people who deserve to be treated with dignity and respect." His approach wasn't just about enforcement it was about building trust, one interaction at a time. Sometimes the most powerful moments happen when duty meets humanity. Kudos to SI and his team!

caption: " ": On 15 November 2025, Station Inspector (SI) Ramdzan and his teammates, Sgt Yi Xiang and Sgt Sherwin from the Police Coast Guard spotted a small fishing boat in Singapore waters. What happened next would touch thousands of hearts online.Seeing two nervous Malaysian fishermen, SI Ramdzan adopted a friendly approach when engaging them. "I told them I understood they might have accidentally entered Singapore waters and they would need to return to Malaysian waters." The fishermen complied immediately.Unknown to him, someone filmed the interaction. The video went viral, with netizens affectionately calling him "Abang Police." His wife's reaction touched him most: "She actually laughed and said she was proud of me."The term "Abang Police" particularly moved him. "When people use that term, there's something much more meaningful behind it. 'Abang' is like calling someone a protective older brother, someone you can trust."SI Ramdzan shared, "Being professional and firm doesn't mean we have to be cold or aggressive. We're dealing with people who deserve to be treated with dignity and respect."His approach wasn't just about enforcement it was about building trust, one interaction at a time. Sometimes the most powerful moments happen when duty meets humanity. Kudos to SI Ramdzan and his team!singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

caption: : , "I was interested in pursuing a career that was meaningful, exciting and could provide opportunities for personal development and growth," Insp Rafid shared, as he looks back at his 28-year career with the SPF. As a trainee at the Old Police Academy in 1996, Insp Rafid applied for a posting to the then-Police Task Force [now the Police Tactical Unit in Special Operations Command (SOC)]. After a six-month attachment to Bedok Police Division, he was posted to SOC in January 1997. Time flew by, and he is still serving in the SOC after 28 years. Insp Rafid candidly shared that he enjoyed the tactical nature of the work, but more importantly, he treasured the camaraderie that existed within the unit.Currently, Insp Rafid serves as a trainer with the SOC. Transitioning from over a decade of frontline operations work to a trainer whilst juggling his family responsibilities as a father of five, presented a major challenge in adapting to an entirely new work environment. As a trainer, he focused on developing his communication and planning abilities to effectively coach and train a diverse range of officers from various SPF units. Insp Rafid shares that despite the challenges with his new role, his colleagues and supervisors supported him and allowed him to successfully navigate this career transition.To aspiring SOC officers, Insp Rafid's advice is to never give up when faced with adversity. "Because it doesn't matter how many times you fall, what matters is the number of times you get back up and become stronger from it. Learn, unlearn, and relearn in this rapidly evolving world. There will always be something new for us to learn and improve upon so that we are better prepared to achieve the mission."Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim. Photos by Ong Lin Hui.spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday

After a six-month attachment to Bedok Police Division, he was posted to SOC in January 1997. Time flew by, and he is still serving in the SOC after 28 years. Insp Rafid candidly shared that he enjoyed the tactical nature of the work, but more importantly, he treasured the camaraderie that existed within the unit. Currently, he serves as a trainer with the SOC. Transitioning from over a decade of frontline operations work to a trainer whilst juggling family responsibilities as a father of five, presented a major challenge in adapting to an entirely new work environment. As a trainer, he focused on developing his communication and planning abilities to effectively coach and train a diverse range of officers from various SPF units. Insp Rafid shares that despite the challenges with his new role, his colleagues and supervisors supported him and allowed him to successfully navigate this career transition. To aspiring SOC officers, Insp Rafid's advice is to never give up when faced with adversity. "Because it doesn't matter how many times you fall, what matters is the number of times you get back up and become stronger from it. Learn, unlearn, and relearn in this rapidly evolving world. There will always be something new for us to learn and improve upon so that we are better prepared to achieve the mission."

This visible show of force can reassure residents of the police's commitment to maintaining public order, especially in a city-state like Singapore, known for its low crime rates and emphasis on security.

The clear identification of police boats, highlighted by the bold "POLICE" markings and unique vessel names, reinforces the presence of law enforcement on the water, reassuring the public and signaling to would-be offenders that Singapore's territorial waters are actively monitored and protected.

caption: - On 10 October 2025, the Singapore Police Force held a graduation parade for 443 Full-time Police National Service (PNS) officers from the 200th Intake. This event was special as we commemorated 50 years of PNS, with the graduands forming the number "50" during the parade - a fitting tribute to this significant milestone! We were honoured to have Ms Sim Ann, Senior Minister of State (SMS) for Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as our Reviewing Officer for this momentous occasion. During her speech, SMS Sim Ann urged the officers to serve their National Service with dedication, embodying the SPF core values of Courage, Loyalty, Integrity and Fairness, to fulfill the SPF mission to prevent, deter and detect crime in Singapore. SMS Sim Ann presented the Total Defence Individual Advocate Awards to 3 Members of Public who have demonstrated outstanding advocacy for National Service. She also presented the Best Trainee Award to 13 graduands for excelling in both their professional studies and physical training while undergoing their basic training in the Police Training Command. These graduands are now ready to begin their next service chapter across various SPF units, putting their training into practice to keep Singapore safe and secure. Their continued commitment in protecting our nation and serving our community continues the proud legacy of five decades of PNS. Our heartiest congratulations to all graduands!singaporepoliceforce NS50

caption: - On 10 October 2025, the Singapore Police Force held a graduation parade for 443 Full-time Police National Service (PNS) officers from the 200th Intake. She also presented the Best Trainee Award to 13 graduands for excelling in both their professional studies and physical training while undergoing their basic training in the Police Training Command. These graduands are now ready to begin their next service chapter across various SPF units, putting their training into practice to keep Singapore safe and secure. caption: : "I hope to contribute to upholding justice and ensuring fairness for everyone," AC Yee Lay shared, reflecting on her SPF career. Growing up drawn to Crimewatch and police dramas, her passion for law enforcement grew during her National Police Cadet Corps years in secondary school and university. Her desire to serve the community pushed her to join the SPF after graduation.Currently, AC Yee Lay is Deputy Director of the SPF's Online Criminal Harms Act (OCHA) Office set up in February 2024 to tackle online criminal harms. OCHA Office works with online service providers and government agencies to safeguard users from online crimes.In her SPF career, AC Yee Lay assisted in post-disaster efforts after the 2004 tsunami as Family Liaison Officer to next-of-kins of missing Singaporeans, reviewed policies after the 2013 Little India Riot, worked on frontline resource allocation during the 2015 SEA Games and oversaw operations at MHA during the 2018 Trump-Kim Summit.As the first female full-time SPF Aide-De-Camp (ADC), she accompanied the President to state functions locally and overseas, including National Day Parade and Cabinet ceremonies. She was Family Liaison Officer during President S R Nathan's lying-in-state in 2016, having served as his ADC from 2010 to 2011. Other highlights include a secondment to MHA as Deputy Director and Deputy Commander of Tanglin Division.As a Police Women's Committee member, AC Yee Lay credits women's progress to determined policewomen who challenged traditional roles. She organises career support through town halls and advocates for enhancing female officers' participation and improving support for working mums.AC Yee Lay also leads the Police Sports Association Netball team, which emerged as Champion at the recent Public Service Netball Tournament!Her advice: "Approach every new role with an open mind when opportunity arises, stay positive and always be ready to learn - you never know what you might discover about yourself." spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: "I hope to contribute to upholding justice and ensuring fairness for everyone," shared AC Yee Lay, reflecting on her SPF career. Growing up drawn to Crimewatch and police dramas, her passion for law enforcement grew during her National Police Cadet Corps years in secondary school and university. Her desire to serve the community pushed her to join the SPF after graduation. Currently, AC Yee Lay is Deputy Director of the SPF's Online Criminal Harms Act (OCHA) Office set up in February 2024 to tackle online criminal harms. The OCHA Office works with online service providers and government agencies to safeguard users from online crimes. In her SPF career, AC Yee Lay assisted in post-disaster efforts after the 2004 tsunami as Family Liaison Officer to next-of-kins of missing Singaporeans, reviewed policies after the 2013 Little India Riot, worked on frontline resource allocation during the 2015 SEA Games, and oversaw operations at MHA during the 2018 Trump-Kim Summit. As the first female full-time SPF Aide-De-Camp (ADC), she accompanied the President to state functions locally and overseas, including National Day Parade and Cabinet ceremonies. She was Family Liaison Officer during the lying-in-state of a former President in 2016, having served as his ADC from 2010 to 2011. Other highlights include a secondment to MHA as Deputy Director and Deputy Commander of Tanglin Division. As a Police Women's Committee member, AC Yee Lay credits women's progress to determined policewomen who challenged traditional roles. She organizes career support through town halls and advocates for enhancing female officers' participation and improving support for working mums. AC Yee Lay also leads the Police Sports Association Netball team, which emerged as Champion at the recent Public Service Netball Tournament! Her advice: "Approach every new role with an open mind when opportunity arises, stay positive and always be ready to learn - you never know what you might discover about yourself."

cleaned_caption:
"I hope to contribute to upholding justice and ensuring fairness for everyone," shared a senior officer reflecting on her SPF career. Growing up drawn to Crimewatch and police dramas, her passion for law enforcement grew during her National Police Cadet Corps years in secondary school and university. Her desire to serve the community pushed her to join the SPF after graduation. Currently, she is Deputy Director of the SPF's Online Criminal Harms Act (OCHA) Office set up in February 2024 to tackle online criminal harms. The OCHA Office works with online service providers and government agencies to safeguard users from online crimes. 

In her SPF career, she assisted in post-disaster efforts after the 2004 tsunami as Family Liaison Officer to next-of-kins of missing Singaporeans, reviewed policies after the 2013 Little India Riot, worked on frontline resource allocation during the 2015 SEA Games and oversaw operations at MHA during the 2018 Trump-Kim Summit. As the first female full-time SPF Aide-De-Camp (ADC), she accompanied the President to state functions locally and overseas, including National Day Parade and Cabinet ceremonies. She was Family Liaison Officer during a lying-in-state event in 2016, having served as ADC from 2010 to 2011. Other highlights include a secondment to MHA as Deputy Director and Deputy Commander of Tanglin Division. 

As a Police Women's Committee member, she credits women's progress to determined policewomen who challenged traditional roles. She organises career support through town halls and advocates for enhancing female officers' participation and improving support for working mothers. She also leads the Police Sports Association Netball team, which emerged as Champion at the recent Public Service Netball Tournament! Her advice: "Approach every new role with an open mind when opportunity arises, stay positive and always be ready to learn - you never know what you might discover about yourself."

"I hope to contribute to upholding justice and ensuring fairness for everyone," shared a senior officer reflecting on her career. Growing up drawn to Crimewatch and police dramas, her passion for law enforcement grew during her National Police Cadet Corps years in secondary school and university. Her desire to serve the community pushed her to join the Singapore Police Force (SPF) after graduation. Currently, she is Deputy Director of the SPF's Online Criminal Harms Act (OCHA) Office, which was set up in February 2024 to tackle online criminal harms. The OCHA Office works with online service providers and government agencies to safeguard users from online crimes. 

In her SPF career, she assisted in post-disaster efforts after the 2004 tsunami as Family Liaison Officer to next-of-kins of missing Singaporeans, reviewed policies after the 2013 Little India Riot, worked on frontline resource allocation during the 2015 SEA Games, and oversaw operations at the Ministry of Home Affairs during the 2018 Trump-Kim Summit. 

As the first female full-time SPF Aide-De-Camp (ADC), she accompanied the President to state functions locally and overseas, including National Day Parade and Cabinet ceremonies. She was Family Liaison Officer during the lying-in-state of a former President in 2016, having served as his ADC from 2010 to 2011. Other highlights include a secondment to the Ministry of Home Affairs as Deputy Director and Deputy Commander of Tanglin Division. 

As a Police Women's Committee member, she credits women's progress to determined policewomen who challenged traditional roles. She organizes career support through town halls and advocates for enhancing female officers' participation and improving support for working mothers. cleaned_caption: "I hope to contribute to upholding justice and ensuring fairness for everyone," shared an Assistant Commissioner of Police, reflecting on her Singapore Police Force (SPF) career. Growing up drawn to Crimewatch and police dramas, her passion for law enforcement grew during her National Police Cadet Corps years in secondary school and university. Her desire to serve the community pushed her to join the SPF after graduation. Currently, she is Deputy Director of the SPF's Online Criminal Harms Act (OCHA) Office set up in February 2024 to tackle online criminal harms. The OCHA Office works with online service providers and government agencies to safeguard users from online crimes. In her SPF career, she assisted in post-disaster efforts after the 2004 tsunami as Family Liaison Officer to next-of-kins of missing Singaporeans, reviewed policies after the 2013 Little India Riot, worked on frontline resource allocation during the 2015 SEA Games, and oversaw operations at the Ministry of Home Affairs during the 2018 Trump-Kim Summit. As the first female full-time SPF Aide-De-Camp (ADC), she accompanied the President to state functions locally and overseas, including National Day Parade and Cabinet ceremonies. She was Family Liaison Officer during the lying-in-state of a former President in 2016, having served as his ADC from 2010 to 2011. Other highlights include a secondment to the Ministry of Home Affairs as Deputy Director and Deputy Commander of Tanglin Division. As a Police Women's Committee member, she credits women's progress to determined policewomen who challenged traditional roles. She organises career support through town halls and advocates for enhancing female officers' participation and improving support for working mums. She also leads the Police Sports Association Netball team, which emerged as Champion at the recent Public Service Netball Tournament! Her advice: "Approach every new role with an open mind when opportunity arises, stay positive and always be ready to learn - you never know what you might discover about yourself."

cleaned_caption:
"I hope to contribute to upholding justice and ensuring fairness for everyone," shared a member of the Singapore Police Force, reflecting on her career. Growing up drawn to Crimewatch and police dramas, her passion for law enforcement grew during her National Police Cadet Corps years in secondary school and university. Her desire to serve the community pushed her to join the Singapore Police Force after graduation. Currently, she is Deputy Director of the Singapore Police Force's Online Criminal Harms Act (OCHA) Office, set up in February 2024 to tackle online criminal harms. The OCHA Office works with online service providers and government agencies to safeguard users from online crimes. 

In her career, she assisted in post-disaster efforts after the 2004 tsunami as Family Liaison Officer to next-of-kins of missing Singaporeans, reviewed policies after the 2013 Little India Riot, worked on frontline resource allocation during the 2015 SEA Games, and oversaw operations at the Ministry of Home Affairs during the 2018 Trump-Kim Summit. As the first female full-time Aide-De-Camp (ADC) of the Singapore Police Force, she accompanied the President to state functions locally and overseas, including the National Day Parade and Cabinet ceremonies. 

Other highlights include a secondment to the Ministry of Home Affairs as Deputy Director and Deputy Commander of Tanglin Division. As a member of the Police Women's Committee, she credits women's progress to determined policewomen who challenged traditional roles. She organizes career support through town halls and advocates for enhancing female officers' participation and improving support for working mothers. She also leads the Police Sports Association Netball team, which emerged as Champion at the recent Public Service Netball Tournament! 

Her advice: "Approach every new role with an open mind when opportunity arises, stay positive and always be ready to learn - you never know what you might discover about yourself."

caption: , From a rookie officer to a top DBS executive, Mr Derrick Gohs 30-year journey in the Police National Service (PNS) is a powerful story of grit, leadership, and heart. As Singapores PNS celebrates 50 years, his incredible story shows how passion and purpose go hand in hand to keep our nation safe and thriving.Balancing a high-powered banking career with policing, Mr Goh proved that true service never takes a backseat. He led operations and innovated fitness training for NS officers. Mr Goh did not just serve he revolutionised the game. He championed modern HomeTeamNS clubhouses that gave officers and their families a place to recharge and connect, building stronger bonds on and off duty.For Mr Goh, PNS is more than a duty its a lifelong commitment to keeping Singapore safe, united, and strong. Heres to the unsung heroes who work tirelessly behind the scenes to shape the future of our nation.safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce pns50

caption: , , For over three decades, Deputy Assistant Commissioner of Police (NS) Lok Weng Hoe, the NS Commander of Central Police Division, has been at the heart of Singapores Police National Service. From his early days of attending to back-to-back 999 calls during the 12-hour patrol shifts to leading the PNS contingent in Central Division, his journey embodies the unwavering spirit and commitment of every PNSman.Balancing his role as a sales director with his NS responsibilities, he acknowledges the vital support of his family and employer, which has enabled him to dedicate himself fully to service. He also credits NS for forging his leadership skills, accountability, and emotional strength qualities that empower him both on duty and in his personal life.In and out of uniform, PNSmen play a vital dual role steadfast protectors on duty and trusted bridges connecting the Police to the community.Never see yourself as just a PNSman. You carry the proud legacy of those who stood the watch before you and you make a difference every day.Heres to the generations whove served and those who will carry the torch forward.safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce pns50
cleaned_caption: For over three decades, Deputy Assistant Commissioner of Police (NS), the NS Commander of Central Police Division, has been at the heart of Singapore's Police National Service. From his early days of attending to back-to-back 999 calls during the 12-hour patrol shifts to leading the PNS contingent in Central Division, his journey embodies the unwavering spirit and commitment of every PNSman. Balancing his role as a sales director with his NS responsibilities, he acknowledges the vital support of his family and employer, which has enabled him to dedicate himself fully to service. He also credits NS for forging his leadership skills, accountability, and emotional strength—qualities that empower him both on duty and in his personal life. caption: The Singapore Police Force (SPF) signs two new agreements to enhance cooperation with the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol).Commissioner of Police Hoong Wee Teck and Europol Executive Director Catherine De Bolle have inked new agreements to enhance multilateral cooperation in the fight against transnational crime.Under the two agreements, the SPF and Europol will strengthen cooperation and collaboration through direct information exchanges via Europols Secure Information Exchange Network Application (SIENA) as well as the deployment of an SPF Liaison Officer to Europol.The SPF looks forward to deepening our partnership with Europol in our collective endeavour against transnational criminality.

caption: : Growing up, SUPT Rimyzad would listen intently to exciting Police stories from his late brother-in-law and elder brother, who were Police Officers. 32 years of service later, SUPT Rimyzad shares fondly of his own experience in the Force.SUPT Rimyzad started his journey in 1993 at the Airport Police Division as a Full-time Police National Service (PNSF) officer and signed on as a regular in 1995. Currently, he is the Head of Operations at Clementi Police Division. Throughout his career, his frontline experience includes working as a patrol officer, managing lock-up operations, conducting investigations, and leading a Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC) as Commanding Officer. He had also served as a planning officer and Head of Operational Logistics at the Police Logistics Department.SUPT Rimyzad is also part of the Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU) - a specialised group of officers who are trained to stay calm in chaos, stepping in with negotiation and communication tactics to save lives during crisis situations such as suicide attempts and hostage incidents. In his role as CNU Team Coordinator, he supports the Ground Commander to ensure a successful resolution to the operation.Drawing from the 23 years of experience in CNU, each crisis intervention has deeply impacted SUPT Rimyzad, with every successful rescue strengthening his commitment to the unit. His belief in police officers as community guardians, and the unwavering support from his team and family, drive his continued service every day Produced by Brenda Teo and Daenia Lim. Photos by Ong Lin Hui and Naveen Raj.spfveterans singaporepoliceforce safeguardingeveryday
cleaned_caption: Growing up, SUPT Rimyzad would listen intently to exciting Police stories from family members who were Police Officers. 32 years of service later, SUPT Rimyzad shares fondly of his own experience in the Force. SUPT Rimyzad started his journey in 1993 at the Airport Police Division as a Full-time Police National Service (PNSF) officer and signed on as a regular in 1995. Currently, he is the Head of Operations at Clementi Police Division. Throughout his career, his frontline experience includes working as a patrol officer, managing lock-up operations, conducting investigations, and leading a Neighbourhood Police Centre (NPC) as Commanding Officer. He had also served as a planning officer and Head of Operational Logistics at the Police Logistics Department. SUPT Rimyzad is also part of the Crisis Negotiation Unit (CNU) - a specialised group of officers who are trained to stay calm in chaos, stepping in with negotiation and communication tactics to save lives during crisis situations such as suicide attempts and hostage incidents. caption: The Singapore Police Force (SPF) hosted the Annual Police Dinner on Thursday, 21 August 2025 to recognise individuals and community partners who have significantly contributed to or closely collaborated with the SPF and commemorated two major milestones: 50th Anniversary (Golden Jubilee) of Police National Service (PNS) Centenary of the SPF BandMinister K Shanmugam joined us as Guest of Honour, where we sealed a commemorative PNS50 time capsule with symbolic items representing our rich heritage and future aspirations such as the SPF200 Medallion, Swagger Stick, Letter to the Future, an Assistant Superintendent of Police peak cap and a SPF jockey cap.A big thank you to our community partners, guests, and officers who joined us in celebrating the enduring bond between SPF and our community safeguardingeveryday singaporepoliceforce pns50
cleaned_caption: The Singapore Police Force (SPF) hosted the Annual Police Dinner on Thursday, 21 August 2025 to recognise individuals and community partners who have significantly contributed to or closely collaborated with the SPF and commemorated two major milestones: 50th Anniversary (Golden Jubilee) of Police National Service (PNS) Centenary of the SPF Band. The Minister for Home Affairs joined us as Guest of Honour, where we sealed a commemorative PNS50 time capsule with symbolic items representing our rich heritage and future aspirations such as the SPF200 Medallion, Swagger Stick, Letter to the Future, an Assistant Superintendent of Police peak cap and a SPF jockey cap. A big thank you to our community partners, guests, and officers who joined us in celebrating the enduring bond between SPF and our community.

caption: : - When multiple 999 calls reported a woman in distress on an overhead bridge in Hougang, officers from both Hougang and Serangoon NPCs raced through rush-hour traffic to get her. What they encountered would test their limits an advertisement board blocking standard rescue approaches, and a woman perched precariously on the wrong side of the railing, her gaze fixed on the traffic flowing five metres below."Each time she moved closer to the edge, my heart sank," recalls Sergeant (SGT) Linus Lim, who maintained crucial first contact. Through veteran instinct, SGT Muhammad Saifuddin spotted their only chance gaps in the railing just wide enough to reach through. When the woman shifted slightly, SGT Saifuddin and his partner Senior Staff Sergeant (SSS) Derrick Lam quickly grasped onto her wrists.ASP Benjamin Cheah and his partner SGT Nuh Irfan made a split-second decision by stepping over the railing and onto a narrow ledge above rushing traffic. Racing along the ledge, ASP Cheah lunged forward, seizing the woman in an iron grip. As she struggled violently, SGT Irfan's grip on his Team Leader's belt became their lifeline. Through the railing gaps, SSS Lam and SGT Saifuddin held on while Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) officers worked to breach the advertisement board.I just followed my Team Leader, says SGT Irfan, just 11 months into service. There was no hesitation because I was focused on the woman and ASP Cheah's safety. Together, they formed a human chain SSS Lam and SGT Saifuddin's grip through the rails, SGT Irfan's anchor hold, and ASP Cheah's grip on her arm.After the board was breached, the SPF and SCDF officers lifted her out to safety.Looking back at that morning, what stands out isn't just what we accomplished, but how we did it, reflects ASP Cheah. When lives are at stake, it's this absolute trust in your team that makes the impossible possible.Their actions that morning earned ASP Cheah and SGT Irfan the Commissioner of Police's High Commendation Award.Written by: Domnic DassPhotos by: Naveen Raj
cleaned_caption: When multiple 999 calls reported a woman in distress on an overhead bridge in Hougang, officers from both Hougang and Serangoon NPCs raced through rush-hour traffic to get her. What they encountered would test their limits: an advertisement board blocking standard rescue approaches and a woman perched precariously on the wrong side of the railing, her gaze fixed on the traffic flowing five metres below. "Each time she moved closer to the edge, my heart sank," recalls Sergeant (SGT) who maintained crucial first contact. Through veteran instinct, SGT spotted their only chance: gaps in the railing just wide enough to reach through. When the woman shifted slightly, SGT and his partner Senior Staff Sergeant (SSS) quickly grasped onto her wrists. ASP and his partner SGT made a split-second decision by stepping over the railing and onto a narrow ledge above rushing traffic. Racing along the ledge, ASP lunged forward, seizing the woman in an iron grip. As she struggled violently, SGT's grip on his Team Leader's belt became their lifeline. Through the railing gaps, SSS and SGT held on while Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) officers worked to breach the advertisement board. "I just followed my Team Leader," says SGT, just 11 months into service. "There was no hesitation because I was focused on the woman and ASP's safety." Together, they formed a human chain: SSS and SGT's grip through the rails, SGT's anchor hold, and ASP's grip on her arm. After the board was breached, the SPF and SCDF officers lifted her out to safety. Looking back at that morning, what stands out isn't just what we accomplished, but how we did it, reflects ASP. When lives are at stake, it's this absolute trust in your team that makes the impossible possible. Their actions that morning earned ASP and SGT the Commissioner of Police's High Commendation Award.
